heading: 6.2 Oceanographic context of Perth Waters and Cockburn Sound
text: Cockburn Sound open bay situated southwestern Australian (SWA) coastal region Indian Ocean. Sound spans area approximately 80 km2 maximum depth 22m (Figure 3.1). bordered coastal line east south, Garden Island west, relatively shallow entrance north (transect Garden Island Woodman Point), depths generally less 5 meters, except narrow shipping channel 15m. geographical features give Sound ‘Mediterranean Sea’ effect, restricted flow southern entrance ocean exchange primarily occurring northern entrance. Anomalies sea level, temperature, salinity, biological activity originating broader Indian ocean can strongly influence properties SWA shelf (e.g. Gaughan Fletcher, 1997; Koslow et al., 2008; Rose et al., 2012).oceanography SWA coastal region characterized combination warm currents climate-driven changes shape marine ecosystems, affecting marine biodiversity coastal processes. region dominated Leeuwin Current, poleward-flowing, warm, nutrient-poor current. current promotes downwelling local upwelling along continental shelf, creates unique marine environment supports warm- cool-water species (Smith et al., 1991; James et al., 1999).Climatic variations, including shifts winter rainfall patterns, closely tied broader atmospheric oceanic circulation systems. Research indicates fluctuations long-term mean sea-level pressure Perth negatively correlated austral winter rainfall, trending downward recent decades, affecting freshwater input coastal dynamics (Allan & Haylock, 1993; Silberstein et al., 2012; Smith & Power, 2014). SWA coastal region also influenced strong northward winds particularly austral summer. sea breezes featured diurnal pattern, rotating anticlockwise direction translating coastal currents, particularly along shoreline within coastal embayment (Pattiaratchi et al., 1999; Gallop et al., 2012). Marine heatwaves, significant event 2011, highlight vulnerability region's ecosystems lead widespread coral bleaching, fish die-offs, harmful algal blooms (Rose et al., 2012).

heading: 7.2 Hydrodynamic setting
text: brief, purposes contextualising model approach, primary driver circulation Cockburn Sound wind, particularly prevailing south-westerly sea breeze summer months. consistent wind pattern induces two-layer circulation surface waters driven northward wind, compensatory return flow develops depth, moving southward. mechanism critical transporting heat, nutrients, properties throughout water column across basin. horizontal shear established flows generally effective promoting vertical mixing, however, periods sustained solar heating calm weather, thermal stratification intensifies, vertical mixing becomes inhibited.pattern stratification typically develops late spring can persist summer early autumn.
